docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on testicular cancer, which is relatively easy to find and treat while still localized; notes that although testicular cancer accounts for only about 1 percent of cancers that afflict American men, it is most common cancer in men ages 15 to 35; says its incidence has been rising greatly in recent decades (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding Lance Armstrong's spectacular victory in the 1999 Tour de France three years after treatment for advanced testicular cancer, there is no question that this disease, which primarily afflicts young men, is best detected and treated while in its early stages, still confined to the testicle in which it developed. Unfortunately, Mr. Armstrong, at age 24, had ignored the early signs of his cancer, and by the time a diagnosis was made, it had spread to his abdomen, lungs and brain. A cancer so advanced required, in addition to surgery, a very challenging course of chemotherapy, which was accompanied by debilitating side effects.
